subject: watchdog: Collect hostboot dump when watchdog times out
commitMessage:
watchdog: Collect hostboot dump when watchdog times out

The hostboot dump collection to be initiated by watchdog_timeout
is disabled by default. When watchdog times out, only error
message corresponding to watchdog timeout is logged. To enable
hostboot dump collection whenever watchdog times out, the meson
option 'hostboot-dump-collection' must be enabled.

Testing - with meson option 'hostboot-dump-collection' enabled:
Ran watchdog_timeout:
case-1: CurrentHostState - off, AutoReboot - false
- Verified PEL object was not created
- Verified hostboot dump was not created
- Verified the Host State changed to Quiesce

case-2: CurrentHostState - off, AutoReboot - true
- Verified PEL object was created
- Verified hostboot dump was not created
- Verified the Host State changed to Running

case-3: CurrentHostState - Running, AutoBoot - false
- Verified PEL object was not created
- Verified hostboot dump was not created
- Verified the Host State changed to Quiesce

case-4: CurrentHostState - Running, AutoBoot - true, default timeout = 300s
- Verified PEL object was created
- Verified hostboot dump was created
- Observed Host state moving to either Running or Quiesce

case-5: CurrentHostState - Running, AutoBoot - true, specified timeout = 5s
- Verified PEL object was created
- Verified hostboot dump was created
- Observed Host state moving to either Running or Quiesce

Docker Unit test: passed

Signed-off-by: Shantappa Teekappanavar <sbteeks@yahoo.com>
Change-Id: Ib92d0c2f282816fb742cf07c1cb876b2cc093c12

can you please change the name of the directory to watchdog_handle or timeout_handle or something similar 
from this statement, this patch is for calling hostboot dump collection during a watchdog timeout, giving directory as hbdump is confusing.

Discussed with Dhruv. 
Will make this change per our discussion:
- change directory name from hbdump to watchdog
- change namespace dump::hbdump to watchdog::dump

Hope it's OK for everyone!
Done
If you click the "..." on the main gerrit page you can set a review as WIP. But I think at this point, you're ready for a real review so you can just remove this.
two words
Done
Done

nit: these are sub-bullets of the first line (i.e. one test where you verified two things)
Did you verify system went to quiesce state after the dump was collected?
What about  some error paths? What if host is not running or hostboot dump interface returns error.
Not sure how to force dump interface return error to verify...
Lets get your automake commit merged to fix this.
Ack

I don't think we've got a lot of need for the more enhanced logging that PRD team uses. Lets just use the normal logging API. Something like this:
log<level::ERR>("Error in AutoReboot Get", entry("ERROR=%s", e.what()));
Done
Put a separator, like @param target - the target..., to separate the input param name and it's description.
Done
General comment made previously on the trace wrapper.
Done

This is more complex then I think you really need. Just call this:
busctl get-property xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host /xyz/openbmc_project/state/host0 xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host CurrentHostState

If it comes back as "xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host.HostState.Running" then request the dump.
Currently this method is unused, and if the the host is in 'Off' state, the hostboot collection is not initiated by phosphor-debug-collector or dump manager. This method/code is removed.
I wonder if we should also have a timeout object going that sets inProgress to false if it expires? We need to ensure we don't get stuck hanging forever if something happens on the dump side.

It is a good idea to have a timeout object that sets inProgress to false if timeout expires, but not sure that should be done by the dump collection requester though. As a requester maybe we can break out of the loop (or throw an exception?) if the difftime(...) exceeds reasonable collection time?

I've been seeing of late the progress status being stuck in "InProgress", and watchdog_timeout just hung there. While I can't figure-out the hostboot entry number to see whether the one I'm seeing corresponds to watchdog_timeout, but the last one is staying in "InProgress". This is something that needs to be addressed sooner or later...

# busctl get-property xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Manager /xyz/openbmc_project/dump/hostboot/entry/20 xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Progress Status
s "xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Progress.OperationStatus.InProgress"

Some design decision should happen to handle changing "InProgress" state...

Yeah, if this service hangs, it hangs the whole recovery path so I think we're going to have to bake a timeout into this code. You can put a TODO in this commit and address in a new patch on top of this one. https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/pldm/+/41005/40/host-bmc/host_pdr_handler.cpp#515 is an example I saw recently doing this. Just create a timer lambda and if it gets called, you timed out. If you get the dump, you just cancel the timer.
Ack
@brief missing
Done
See previous comments. This is a pretty simple application, I don't think it really needs an extra layer of logging over the normal phosphor-logging API's.
Done
I think eventually this logic will be handled by the dump code but for now I think this is good for lab debug.
Ack
I think this is redundant now? Doesn't your new code generate and report the error?

I was kind of debating on this, and left it here to get reviewers opinion. We have/create an error reporting PEL object that will have the error info about WatchdogTimeout. I'm not sure whether that is considered as reporting error. If it is considered as error reporting then I can delete this...
Yeah, same thing so you can delete this.
Done
"PELi"? Also, we'll need to get this test finished and documented before we can merge
Done
I don't see this in other commits in this repo, e.g. https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openpower-debug-collector/+/43228/15/dump/dump_manager.hpp

This creates a method for the specified path, interface, and function (CreateDump) which is called in requestDump - https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openpower-debug-collector/+/44354/3/watchdog/watchdog_dbus.hpp. The created method takes two parameters, DumpType and ErrorLogId to create hostboot dump. 

This has nothing to do with other work that Dhruv is doing to create SBE dumps.

The use of the i_ to represent an input variable comes from our old FSP days. OpenBMC in general has not used the i_. I think you based this code on what was in the hw-diags repo which was based on that older code. Since there's no other use in this repo of the i_ pattern, I think it's best to just remove it from this commit. Maintainers can weigh in though.
Done
Remove this if we go with SIGALRM approach. See my other comment...
Is there any standard practice of using @param vs @param[in/out]?
No, you can add the [in/out] if you like to signify and input/output parameter but it's not required.

Couldn't get this piece of code to work - it did not call callback. I plan to delete this if alternative of using SIGALRM is acceptable. If not, I need some help to get it to working...
Jayanth/Andrew: any suggestion?

Patrick provided some background in discord on this, sdeventplus and sdbusplus are two different implementations that do the same thing. sdbusplus is a bit simpler but does not provide timer support like sdeventplus does. You can only use one or the other. Since you need timer support you should use sdeventplus. https://grok.openbmc.org/xref/openbmc/sdeventplus/example/heartbeat_timer.cpp?r=1b49b6f0 is an example of the timer.

nit: this seems a bit overboard? Just standard stuff seems more readable here.
bool timedOut = false;
Done

nit: put logic statements in their own () to make order clear.
while ((true == inProgress) && !timedOut)
Done

This isn't as efficient as having everything running asynchronously with callbacks and timer events but it gets the job done, and realistically the BMC is not doing much else other then waiting for this to complete.
Ack

We may need to revisit this some day. Maybe log an error, maybe make sure we cancel the dump service so it's not still running when we move the system into a quiesce state. But we can build on this later.
Ack
Changed the wait time from 1 microsecond to 1 second since it is not necessary to check the dump progress status that frequently.
Could just use something like std::chrono::microseconds() but this works too.
Done

One thing I didn't think about was backwards compatibility. We'll need a meson option combined with a compile flag that defaults to the old way of doing things (just creating the error) on non-P10 systems.
#ifdef CREATE_ERROR_ONLY
<old code>
report<error>();
#else
run all the new code
#endif
Done
This statement is ot completely correct. attn path hostbootdump is enabled.  this statement is true from watchdump context.please update the statement
Done

I'm not a big fan of the config file. It's pretty non-standard to how other repos have utilized this. I think just a "#ifdef HOSTBOOT_DUMP_COLLECTION" in the code is fine vs. all these hoops to try and make a variable.
Done
start using libfmt librarry. this will help to get data in journal logs directly without son-pretty option.

Patrick has a push going to get rid of the libfmt usage via https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-logging/+/45310 so my vote is we wait for that to settle and then move this repo to the new lg2 interfaces he's created.
See previous comment, I'd just prefer the #ifdef path.
Done
Instead of all of this, can you just check the config variable in meson and just not add these source files to the watchdog application within the meson.build file if the build option is not set?
Done
This is a bit confusing to read. Could we just use watchdog_lib and define it as empty if hostboot-dump-collection is not enabled, otherwise we'll use what the watchdog subdir sets it to?
Done
nit: error? Something a little more generic since it's not always going to collect a hostboot dump.
Came up with something, but still a head scratcher for me to make it generic for both collection and error out 😞

nit: This seems a bit overly complex. Could it just be:
uint32_t timeoutInterval = 1500;
Done
This option is only really relevant for the HOSBOOT_DUMP_COLLECTION path, can we move into that #ifdef?
Done
I would just move all of this code into the #ifdef below lines 26-29. There's no need for the CLI function to support the legacy stuff.

argc and argv are not used in legacy code. This will cause build error for legacy code. Do you want me to have main(...) on both blocks of #ifdef or add something like (void)argc and (void**)argv in the #else block to avoid build error?

When this app is going to start , after Hostboot start of after host start traget completion? 
If this starts early , need to look the window SBE boot or Hostboot boot. by using pdbg interfaces on primarr processor.(  https://github.com/open-power/pdbg/blob/master/libpdbg/libpdbg_sbe.h#L127. ) . And if it is in SBE boot window , should trigger SBE dump ( support still not in place yet) . Please add todo incase this is not considered inthe existing flow
Done
